esquire definition: a member of the English gentry ranking below a knight.
Esquire (band), an English progressive and symphonic rock band
Esquire is a title used to denote that a man (among lawyers in the United States, a man or a woman) has a certain social status

Burglars steal Milan Lučić's Memorial Cup ring from his Vancouver home

wiki.text:
'Esquire' (abbreviated 'Esq.')<ref>'esquire, n.1' and 'esq., n.1.3.a.': Oxford
English Dictionary Online: Accessed October 4, 2011 00:41BST</ref> is a term of
West European origin. In the United States, the nominal suffix "Esquire" or
"Esq." generally designates individuals licensed to practice law.<ref
name="Tussle Over Titles">Thompson, Kathryn.
[http://abajournal.com/magazine/tussle_over_titles/ Tussle Over Titles],
[[American_Bar_Association#Publications|ABA Journal]], January 2006.</ref>

In the United Kingdom, it is a title of respect previously accorded to men of
higher social rank,<ref>[http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=XqZFAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA1-
029&lpg=PA1029&dq=the+justices+of+the+peace+in+quarter+sessions+assembled+of+wh-
ich+no+less+than+shall+be+of+the+quorum&source=bl&ots=HYwq9hTHiH&sig=1vQpgtUJo3-
4cNFYu4W4fK0DoOpw&hl=en&ei=iVqVTqTeMM-
v8QPRuamABw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&sqi=2&ved=0CB4Q6AEwAA#v=onep-
age&q=the%20justices%20of%20the%20peace%20in%20quarter%20sessions%20assembled%2-
0of%20which%20no%20less%20than%20shall%20be%20of%20the%20quorum&f=false The
Statutes of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland, vol. 25] see
statutoril prescribed post-nominal titles of L.M. and N.O. in Schedule B. Form
of Certificate.</ref> but which has since come to be used as a general courtesy
title for any man in a formal context, usually appended to the name as in "John
Smith, Esq.", with no precise significance.<ref name="dictionary.com1">esquire.
Dictionary.com Unabridged. Random House, Inc. 3 May. 2010. [Dictionary.com
http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/esquire].</ref><ref name="oed">Oxford
English Dictionary, second edition (1991)</ref> Esquire is cognate with the word
squire, which originally meant an apprentice or assistant to a knight. The title
"Esquire" has been used continuously since it was created in the late 14th
century and many uses continue uninterrupted today. For example, in the Most
Venerable Order of the Hospital of Saint John of Jerusalem, "Esquire" is the
most junior title.
wiki.title: esquire
